Name: Moore, Blake D.
text:
The security environment in the Middle East is rapidly changing as we speak. I‚Äôm hesitant to offer definitive analysis in a time of such uncertainty, but here are a few core observations of mine from the past few days:
1) Israel‚Äôs clear-eyed decision to strike and dismantle a rogue Iranian nuclear program, one that was censured by UN authorities last week for breaching the Non-Proliferation Treaty, is firmly within the U.S. national interest. It‚Äôs a good thing that Iran‚Äôs ability to threaten the U.S., Israel, and our other allies with the nuclear weapon has now been degraded.

2) I‚Äôm glad that the White House has made clear that they are prioritizing the safety of our servicemembers in the region and the 500,000+ Americans living in Israel. They do not want to spark a wider regional war, and neither do I.

3) Conventional air superiority still reigns supreme. Drones/unmanned tech will continue to play a major role in the future of warfare but, as we saw, they cannot replace fifth generation aircraft. Utahns know this well with Hill Air Force Base being home to the nation‚Äôs first active duty F-35 wing. 

4) There is a quietly-growing consensus from our European and Arab partners that the best possible outcome is one where Iran can no longer possess a nuclear weapon. This consensus is long overdue.

5) Lastly, I realize this would be very difficult to achieve with the Ayotollah‚Äôs firm grip on power and the IRGC‚Äôs omnipresence, but I desperately hope this conflict leads to an opportunity for the amazing Iranian people to recapture a voice within their government and create more of their own destiny.

Name: Collins, Mike
text:
On this day in history in 1944, the U.S. launched a two-day assault on Japan's naval air power in the Battle of the Philippine Sea, effectively ending Japan‚Äôs ability to conduct large-scale carrier operations.

It was the last of five major carrier-versus-carrier battles between American and Japanese forces. The clash involved 24 aircraft carriers and approximately 1,350 carrier-based aircraft, making it the largest carrier battle in history.

The aerial phase became known as the ‚ÄúGreat Marianas Turkey Shoot‚Äù due to the lopsided losses suffered by Japanese forces. American pilots, backed by superior training, tactics, and advanced anti-aircraft defenses, dominated the skies. A pilot from the USS Lexington famously remarked, ‚ÄúWhy, hell, it was just like an old-time turkey shoot down home!‚Äù The American victory crippled Japan‚Äôs naval air power and cemented U.S. dominance in the Pacific.

Name: Golden, Jared F.

Today we reflect, we remember, and we celebrate all those who have contributed to the cause of freedom. Happy Juneteenth.

Name: Houlahan, Chrissy
text:
Juneteenth marks the joyous day in 1865 that news of freedom reached the last enslaved people in the country - three full years after the Emancipation Proclamation was signed.  
 
This year, I had the honor of speaking in Reading as the Juneteenth flag was raised over the city.  
 
Juneteenth reminds us that Black history is foundational to American history and deserves to be shared, taught, and celebrated. It deserves to be protected. 
 
Thank you to the City of Reading for having me - and happy Juneteenth!

Not only is Frederick Douglass an abolitionist icon & an American hero, but he was the first Black reporter admitted to the House Press Gallery.

Name: Donalds, Byron
text:
Frederick Douglass was born into slavery in 1818. After courageously escaping bondage in 1838, he built a life dedicated to truth, liberty, and justice. He became a journalist in Rochester, New York, and launched The North Star using his own money, giving voice to the voiceless in the years before the Civil War.

He fought fiercely against slavery, championed equal rights and women‚Äôs suffrage, and became one of the most forceful orators in American history. During the Civil War, Douglass recruited Black soldiers, met with President Lincoln to advocate for equal pay and treatment, and worked to assist those escaping slavery.

Name: Donalds, Byron
text:
After his Rochester home was destroyed in a suspected arson attack, he moved to Washington, D.C. and became editor ‚Äî and later owner ‚Äî of the New National Era, which chronicled Black progress throughout the nation.

Douglass was the first Black reporter admitted to the Capitol press galleries. From 1871 to 1875, he reported on House and Senate action, keeping the African American community informed during Reconstruction after the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments. He spent countless hours writing and studying in the House Press Gallery.

Even after his tenure in the gallery, he returned often to the Capitol.

For generations, he poured his heart into this program and left a lasting mark on every player who wore the uniform.

Name: Nadler, Jerrold
text:
As I told ICE yesterday, the Trump Administration has no legal right to block Members of Congress from inspecting DHS-operated facilities used to detain or house undocumented immigrants.

The law is clear: Section 527 of the 2024 Consolidated Appropriations Act prohibits this and does not require prior notice, though I notified ICE in advance of my intent to conduct oversight.

ICE is wrongly claiming its field offices are exempt, even when they admit that undocumented immigrants are being forced to sleep on the floor there for nights at a time.

But the law doesn‚Äôt care what ICE calls a facility. If it‚Äôs used for any length of detention, as the site at 26 Federal Plaza clearly is, Congress has the right to inspect it. Period.

Name: McBride, Sarah
text:
Today, we honor Juneteenth‚ÄîFreedom Day. On June 19, 1865, more than two years after the Emancipation Proclamation, news of freedom finally reached enslaved people in Galveston, Texas. 

But Juneteenth is more than just a date. It‚Äôs a call to action to never give up on the hard work of building a more perfect Union. To never give up on the efforts‚Äîand in many cases the sacrifices‚Äîof those who pushed for freedom. And that because of their hard work‚Äîthrough the all too slow progress of change‚Äîjustice arrived like a thunderbolt.

It was an honor to host my friends U.S. Rep. @repcleaver, Rep. @RepPressley, and Mayor Bob Sullivan at @MassasoitCC  for a Congressional Public Housing Caucus Forum on Federal Affordable and Public Housing. As proud products of public housing, Rep. Cleaver and I established this Caucus to work with local leaders, non-profit organizations, community advocates, and the business community to help address a national housing crisis that includes a shortage of more than 7 million affordable homes for America‚Äôs working families.
¬†
We heard from experts on the need for immediate federal action to increase funding for public housing, preserve and modernize existing housing,¬†expand¬†rental assistance, and¬†advance other urgent priorities in this area. Special thanks to all who participated and attended, including Mayor Bob Sullivan (@CityBrockton) , Joe Kriesberg (@MassINC), Gilbert Winn (@WinnCompanies), Robert Corley (@neighborworks), Susan Chu (@dbedc), Joseph Goncalves (New Vision Enterprise), Rachel Heller (Citizens‚Äô Housing¬†and Planning Association), Thomas Thibeault (@BrocktonHousing), Aaron Gornstein (Preservation of Affordable Housing), and Sarah Byrnes (Mass Union of Public Housing Tenants), and for all you do on behalf of our communities.

Name: Fitzpatrick, Brian K.
text:
Two years ago, our community lost 5-year-old Wesley Roche of Richboro‚Äîa heartbreaking loss that continues to echo through all of us who have come to know his story.

Last year, I had the honor of standing with his extraordinary parents, Nicole and Alex, to dedicate Wesley‚Äôs Playground at the Middletown Grange Fairgrounds‚Äîa space that reflects Wesley‚Äôs spirit and the strength of a family determined to turn grief into purpose. Since then, I‚Äôve had the privilege of working alongside Nicole and Alex as partners in this fight and friends in this mission.

As Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I carry Wesley‚Äôs story with me in our work to expand pediatric cancer research funding, improve access to clinical trials, and ensure federal agencies prioritize the unique needs of children battling cancer.

Wesley‚Äôs legacy is powerful, and helping to bring about real change. Today, and every day, we remember him with purpose and hold the Roche family close in our hearts.

Name: Elfreth, Sarah
text:
During the Jim Crow era, Sparrow‚Äôs and Carr‚Äôs Beach was more than just a shoreline ‚Äì it was a sanctuary. As one of the most popular beaches in the country for African American families, the landmark drew legends like Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, James Brown, and more. 

In honor of #Juneteenth, @AnnapolisRec brought the spirit of the resort‚Äôs heyday back to life (despite the heat!) and together, we celebrated the joy and community that Carr‚Äôs Beach brought for so many. Black history is American history ‚Äì and from the State House to Capitol Hill ‚Äì I‚Äôm committed to preserving and telling the stories like Carr‚Äôs Beach for generations to come.

Name: Morrison, Kelly
text:
Last night we gathered to honor the lives of Melissa and Mark Hortman at the Minnesota Capitol.

Melissa was a remarkable person. She was a gifted legislator, a tough negotiator, a coalition builder, a strong and compassionate leader, and a mentor to so many, including me. She was relentless in her efforts to make Minnesota a better place for everyone, and I think she will be remembered as the most consequential Speaker of the House in Minnesota history. 

It was incredibly meaningful to see so many people show up to pay their respects and to grieve together. This is an immense loss and we will need to support each other as we walk through this. 

As Melissa and Mark‚Äôs children said in their beautiful statement: 

‚ÄúHope and resilience are the enemy of fear. Our parents lived their lives with immense dedication to their fellow humans. This tragedy must become a moment for us to come together. Hold your loved ones a little closer. Love your neighbors. Treat each other with kindness and respect. The best way to honor our parents‚Äô memory is to do something, whether big or small, to make our community just a little better for someone else.‚Äù

Frank served with distinction in both the Tennessee House and Senate, always standing firm for what he believed in. He was a tireless voice for agriculture, landowners, and personal freedom, never afraid to speak his mind or challenge the status quo.

He was not only a statesman, but also a friend to many and a man deeply rooted in faith, family, and service.

My heartfelt prayers are with his family and loved ones. May God comfort them during this time, and may we never forget the legacy Frank Niceley leaves behind.

Name: Cuellar, Henry
text:
This afternoon in Starr County, it was a pleasure to join the @SCMH1975 Board and administrative team for a roundtable discussion about protecting healthcare in our community.

We met as rural healthcare faces serious threats. Proposed federal cuts to Medicaid and rollbacks to the Affordable Care Act would devastate access to care, putting over 54,000 people in TX-28 at risk of losing coverage, including 46,000 through Medicaid alone.

Texas already runs one of the most efficient Medicaid programs in the country. These GOP cuts could strip up to $55 billion in funding, threaten 142,000 healthcare jobs, and severely impact rural hospitals, many of which already operate at a loss.

Rural hospitals like Starr County Memorial are the backbone of our communities. We must protect the coverage, services, and jobs they provide.

I am grateful to the Hospital Board and team for their leadership, and I will keep fighting in Congress to ensure our communities in South Texas get the care and support they deserve.

Name: Fitzpatrick, Brian K.
text:
Each week, we share stories from across our district of individuals who go above and beyond in service to others‚Äîwho lead not for recognition but out of a deep and abiding commitment to their community.
 
Today, we shine a light on a man who has exemplified that spirit every day for the last 35 years. Meet this week's Hometown Hero: Lieutenant John Michniewicz of the Middletown Township Police Department.

Lieutenant Michniewicz began his law enforcement journey in 1990, graduating from the Philadelphia Police Academy with a clear and unwavering mission: to serve and protect our community. Over the next three and a half decades, he became a cornerstone of the Middletown Township Police Department‚Äîrising through the ranks as Patrolman, K-9 Officer, Detective, Sergeant, and ultimately Lieutenant. In every role, he led by example, bringing a deep sense of duty, professionalism, and compassion that elevated the entire department and set a lasting standard for those who served alongside him.
 
This week, I had the honor of joining MTPD To celebrate Lieutenant Michniewicz as he prepares to retire after 35 years of distinguished service. As someone who works closely with our law enforcement officers day in and day out, I witness the strength, sacrifice, and dedication it takes to protect our communities, and Lieutenant Michniewicz embodies all of that and more. He has not only earned the respect of his fellow officers but also the trust and admiration of our entire community. His leadership, steady presence, and unwavering commitment to public safety have left a lasting mark on Middletown, and his legacy will continue to guide the department for years to come.
 
Beyond his day-to-day service, Lieutenant Michniewicz played a critical role in preparing the department for the future. He conducted countless background investigations to ensure recruits met the highest standards of character and professionalism. He also made a strong commitment to developing his professional leadership, graduating from some of the most respected law enforcement programs in the country, including Northwestern University‚Äôs School of Police Staff and Command, the Police Executive Research Forum‚Äôs Senior Management Institute, and the FBI‚Äôs Executive Development Program. Through his example and mentorship, he helped raise the bar for policing‚Äînot just in Middletown but across our region.
 
Please join me in congratulating Lieutenant John Michniewicz on his well-earned retirement and thanking him, along with all our brave officers, for their selfless service, steadfast commitment, and unwavering protection of our community.

Name: Schneider, Bradley Scott
text: Our Constitutional right to free speech (defined in the 1st Amendment) means we will not always agree, and may even be profoundly offended by the ideas, positions and rhetoric of our neighbors and fellow citizens. But in the same way we cannot deny their voice, neither can our voice be silenced.

Name: Schneider, Bradley Scott
text:
Our Constitutional right to due process (defined in the 5th Amendment) means we cannot be lifted off the streets or taken from our homes to be locked away or sent to foreign lands. Due process protects the innocent, not the guilty. The absolute right to due process means all Americans can have confidence in our freedoms, in our homes, and in our persons.

I am not a judge, but I think the Court has made the proper decision in this case.

Name: Nadler, Jerrold
text:
I welcome today‚Äôs decision directing the release of Mahmoud Khalil. 

As I have said before, his prolonged detention‚Äîwithout charges‚Äîis a chilling, McCarthyesque action in response to the exercise of First Amendment rights to free speech and raises serious constitutional concerns. While I do not agree with all of the content of Mr. Khalil‚Äôs protected speech, we must protect these rights even and especially of those who exercise protected speech we disagree with. The court‚Äôs decision today affirms the principles of due process and civil liberties that must remain at the core of our country‚Äôs values and rule of law.

Today‚Äôs decision is a welcome rebuke of the Trump Administration‚Äôs weaponization of antisemitism for their own political gain. Indeed, as I have said, if the Trump White House were serious about rooting out antisemitism in America, they should start with their own Administration.

Name: Leger Fernandez, Teresa
text:
It would be incredibly dangerous for Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon. I am concerned that the current war could rapidly spiral into a broader war in the Middle East, with grave consequences for regional stability and American lives.

But let‚Äôs be clear: the authority to declare war belongs solely to the United States Congress. President Trump does not have congressional approval to take offensive military action against Iran.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve signed onto the bipartisan War Powers resolution to prohibit U.S. involvement in the Israel-Iran war without congressional approval.

I have called on Speaker Johnson to immediately reconvene the House to respond to possible military action in Iran. He must also immediately convene a classified congressional briefing on the escalating conflict.

But let‚Äôs remember how we got here: although imperfect, the Obama administration negotiated a nuclear agreement that successfully and verifiably prevented Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. President Trump recklessly withdrew from that deal, removing restrictions and giving Iran a green light to resume its nuclear ambitions.

We must work with our allies to pursue a diplomatic resolution‚Äîone that ends Iran‚Äôs nuclear program and makes sure it cannot threaten Israel or regional peace. Diplomacy, backed by strength and coordination, remains our best path forward.

Name: Suozzi, Thomas R.
text:
Earlier today, I joined a bipartisan group of elected officials and stakeholders from both sides of Long Island Sound to celebrate 40 years of progress in restoring and protecting this vital resource. Together, we endorsed a 10-year plan aimed at revitalizing the Sound as an essential ecological, economic, and recreational treasure.

Throughout my 30-plus years in public service, I have committed myself to cleaning up pollution in and around Long Island Sound. This has included reducing nitrogen emissions from sewage treatment plants, addressing stormwater runoff, and restoring and reseeding shellfishing beds in our harbors. Since I came to Congress in 2017, I have secured a 1,000% increase in funding to enhance the Long Island Sound.

Protecting and preserving Long Island Sound‚Äîour ‚ÄúNational Park‚Äù‚Äîis a top priority and a shared responsibility. I am thankful for the bipartisan and collaborative efforts of many individuals, and I am encouraged by the EPA's commitment to revitalizing the Sound for future generations.

Name: Welch, Peter
text:
Last week, Secretary Kennedy fired the entire the CDC vaccine advisory panel tasked with advising the government on who should receive which vaccines and when.

Let's take a look at who he appointed to replace them. üßµ 

Dr. Joseph R. Hibbeln, who has no professional track record at all with vaccines.

Martin Kulldorff objected to mass vaccinations for COVID-19, and himself neglected to get one. He was later dismissed by Mass General Brigham and fired from Harvard Medical School. He's also accepted over $30,000 in return for testifying against vaccines. 

Dr. Retsef Levi, a professor at MIT, has used his profile to call for the termination of COVID vaccines, wrongly claiming they caused a record number of deaths.  

Dr. Robert Malone claimed the American people got COVID-19 vaccinations because they were, in part, hypnotized. He inaccurately said some of those vaccinated then developed AIDS. 

Despite being on the FDA panel that approved COVID vaccines, Dr. Cody Meissner has argued repeatedly against children receiving them. He criticized children wearing masks during COVID, even though the practice saved lives.  

Dr. Michael A. Ross is an OB-GYN and a board member for a supplement company. He has no public vaccine experience at all. 

Dr. James Pagano, an emergency medicine physician, has no public professional experience with vaccines.

Finally, Vicky Pebsworth volunteered as a director for a medical group spreading widespread misinformation on vaccines. 

This panel is supposed to be made up of experts who use science to make recommendations that will keep the public safe. His choices are conspiracy theorists and unexperienced doctors who will put our health at risk.

Name: Fitzpatrick, Brian K.
text:
Today, I had the great honor of celebrating the launch of https://t.co/9yBaRAE1km‚Äîa groundbreaking national platform founded by my friend and partner, the extraordinary Matt Bellina of Northampton.

Matt‚Äîa Navy veteran, father of three, and ALS warrior‚Äîcreated this first-of-its-kind space to connect, empower, and uplift everyone impacted by ALS. While he couldn‚Äôt be there in person today, his incredible mom, Deb, represented him with strength, heart, and the same unwavering commitment to this mission.

Matt‚Äôs courageous advocacy helped shape my Right to Try Act, now law‚Äîgiving terminally ill patients access to hope when time is short. And now, through https://t.co/9yBaRAE1km, he‚Äôs once again turning his fight into something that will uplift and support others.

As Co-Chair of the bipartisan ALS Caucus, I‚Äôm proud to stand with Matt and his family in this fight. Together, we will keep fighting to deliver the answers, treatments, and the future the ALS community so rightly deserves.

At its heart is the incomparable Diane Reitz, whose bravery in her battle against cancer is matched only by her unwavering devotion to our nation‚Äôs heroes. Name: Cuellar, Henry
text:
Today in Webb County, I visited two families whose homes have been repaired thanks to a $2 million federal earmark I secured to improve housing conditions in Webb and Zapata counties.

The federal funds, with $1 million for Webb County and $1 million for Zapata County, were awarded to @nwlaredo to weatherize and repair dozens of homes in rural communities like El Cenizo, Rio Bravo, Mirando City, and Oilton. These critical renovations lower utility costs, increase accessibility through ADA-compliant upgrades, and provide safe, livable housing for families who too often lack access to home improvement resources.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I was proud to secure this funding through the Community Project Funding process. In Webb County, Phase 1 of the project is already complete, with 17 homes repaired in El Cenizo and Rio Bravo. Phase 2 is now in progress, with work underway in Mirando City and Oilton.

This investment is more than just construction. It is about ensuring dignity, safety, and long-term savings for families in need.

Thank you to NeighborWorks Laredo CEO Elizabeth Alonzo-Villarreal, Rio Bravo Mayor Amanda Perez Aguero, El Cenizo Mayor Carina Hernandez, our local leaders, and the contractors on the ground for turning this funding into meaningful change. I will keep working to deliver results for our communities.

Seguir√© trabajando con todo mi esfuerzo para traer resultados concretos a nuestras comunidades. ¬°Vamos a seguir adelante!

Name: Plaskett, Stacey E.
text:
As we close out Caribbean American Heritage Month, I'm reminded of the countless ways Caribbean Americans have enriched our nation üá∫üá∏üå¥

From the flavors in our kitchens to the rhythms at our festivals, from classrooms to courtrooms, Caribbean Americans continue to strengthen America's tapestry. We are entrepreneurs, educators, artists, and leaders who embody the values of hard work, family, and community.

Our story is one of transforming challenges into opportunities while preserving our vibrant culture. We've colored the American landscape with Caribbean vibrancy and continue to advance our nation's promise of diversity and inclusion.

To all my fellow Caribbean Americans: your contributions matter, your heritage is celebrated, and your impact on America is profound.
Happy Caribbean American Heritage Month! üéâ
#CaribbeanAmericanHeritageMonth #ProudlyCaribbean #USVI

Name: Collins, Mike
text:
On this day in history in 1788, the Constitution was ratified. 

Following the Revolutionary War, Congress approved the drafting of a new constitution. After three months of debate at the Constitutional Convention, 38 of the 41 delegates signed the final document. By May 1790, all 13 original colonies had ratified it and formally joined the United States.

Today, the U.S. Constitution stands as the oldest written national constitution still in use.

Name: Meuser, Daniel
text:
Whether you take a broad view of the economy or focus squarely on the Fed‚Äôs dual mandate, the case for easing is increasingly clear. Chairman Powell deserves credit for navigating some of the toughest terrain in modern history with record spending from the Biden Administration during COVID. But with inflation cooling and a strong labor market, the upside of lower rates is becoming hard to miss.

As the U.S. gears up to pass the One Big Beautiful Bill‚Äîa generational investment in American industry and innovation‚Äîlower rates would supercharge private-sector growth, unlock long-term capital, and help usher in a new golden era of economic dynamism. A rate cut would also kickstart the housing market, which carries powerful multipliers across jobs, materials, and consumer demand.

It would also ease pressure on the federal government‚Äôs debt service costs, made worse by years of unchecked Biden-era spending.

The moment is here. We‚Äôre building momentum. Get on board, Mr. Chairman.

Name: Whitesides, George
text:
Yesterday, I attempted to enter the Adelanto ICE Processing Center following reports that the father of one of my constituents was detained after reporting for a scheduled asylum check. I was denied access for oversight of the facility, but was later able to meet Randal in person. 

I have been clear from day one: we need to put politics aside to work on bipartisan immigration reform and secure our Southern border while still ensuring there are legal and dignified pathways to citizenship. But punishing those who are following all the rules, including ripping them away from their families, does not move us towards a more secure system -- it is cruel and un-American.

As I look into the circumstances behind Randal‚Äôs detention, I encourage you to read and share his story:

Name: Whitesides, George

Name: Watson Coleman, Bonnie
text:
The United States has just committed an act of war against a country that posed no imminent threat to our people. There was no self-defense or tactical strategy taken into account. Just the reckless action of a man who has never understood or respected the responsibilities of American leadership.

This war was provoked by Benjamin Netanyahu for his own political survival, and Donald Trump has willingly handed him American military power to prolong it. The United States is not anyone‚Äôs proxy army, and our troops are not bargaining chips.

Trump had no legal authority to unilaterally launch these attacks. Congress has not authorized military force against Iran. In bypassing both the Constitution and our intelligence community - which made clear that Iran is not currently pursuing a nuclear weapon - he has once again demonstrated that he is a danger to our democracy and to global peace.

The American people do not want yet another unnecessary preemptive war in the Middle East. Now, instead of preventing war, we are embroiled in one - not for our security, but for the ego of two men who think they are above accountability.¬†

I grieve for every family that will pay the price for this war. I am calling on Congress to immediately reassert its constitutional authority and pass the Massie-Khanna War Powers Resolution to halt further unauthorized military action and to stand up to this irrational and reckless behavior before more lives are lost.

By destroying Iran‚Äôs nuclear sites, President Trump demonstrated bold leadership, unshakable resolve, and an unwavering commitment to safeguarding our homeland and our allies.

Name: Meuser, Daniel
text:
Despite a months-long, good-faith diplomatic effort led by President Trump, the Iranian regime refused to abandon its nuclear ambitions. Every opportunity for a peaceful resolution was rejected. Tonight‚Äôs action was both justified and necessary.

The United States has carried out a successful, targeted strike on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities at Fordow, Natanz, and Esfahan. This operation sends a clear and unmistakable message: Iran must never be allowed to obtain a nuclear weapon.

These sites were at the core of a regime that funds terror, destabilizes the region, and threatens America and its allies. A nuclear-armed Iran would endanger Israel, inflict global instability, and put countless lives at risk.

Thanks to the extraordinary precision of our Armed Forces, the mission was executed flawlessly, and all aircraft returned safely.

Peace through strength is the only path forward. The United States must remain committed to dismantling Iran‚Äôs nuclear program and standing with our allies against terror. We continue to hope that Iran will finally come to the table and help forge a lasting peace in the Middle East.

Name: Bergman, Jack
text:
Having served 40 years in the Marine Corps ‚Äî many of those as an aviator ‚Äî I can say with confidence that today‚Äôs U.S. strikes on three nuclear sites in Iran showcased truly impressive precision.

President Trump has long made it clear: Iran must never possess a nuclear weapon ‚Äî and the American people overwhelmingly agree. The President gave Iran's leader an opportunity to make a deal, but Iran refused to commit to a nuclear disarmament agreement. 

By leveraging the unmatched precision of the U.S. military, the President has sent a clear message to the world about what peace through strength truly means. This was not a knee-jerk response, and knowing President Trump, he has no interest in dragging America into another endless war. 

The Iranian people are at a pivotal moment ‚Äî with an opportunity to push back against a brutal regime and demand the basic human rights and freedoms they‚Äôve been denied for too long, especially the women who have endured decades of oppression.

Name: Smith, Adam
text:
My statement on Trump ordering U.S. strikes on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities:

I condemn in the strongest terms the President‚Äôs decision to order the U.S. military to strike Iran‚Äôs nuclear sites. The President did not seek authorization from Congress or demonstrate that Iran posed an immediate threat to the security of the United States. Furthermore, the President failed to provide clear objectives for these actions and there are no guarantees that it will eliminate the possibility of Iran developing a nuclear weapon or how long it might set their program back.
¬†
Engaging in direct conflict places U.S. service members and military sites in the Middle East squarely in the crosshairs of Iran and its many proxies. Tonight‚Äôs actions could further escalate tensions, destabilize the region, and drag the United States into an avoidable war.

The way to stop Iran from developing a nuclear weapon and to protect American service members is through diplomacy and negotiation, not entering into direct conflict. The path that the President has chosen risks unleashing a wider war in the region that is both incredibly unpredictable and treacherous and that threatens the safety and security of the United States, Israel, and ultimately the world.

Name: Courtney, Joe
text:
Four-star Army General David Petraeus' famous 2003 maxim about the Iraq War, "tell me how this ends", should be at the forefront in the mind of every American, particularly President Trump, who hit Iran with military force without a declaration of war which the Constitution clearly requires. 

As our nation learned the hard way in Iraq and Afghanistan, it is easier to start a war in the Middle East, than to end one. As a member of the Armed Services Committee, I will be pushing to assert Congressional authority and oversight, particularly focused on force protection of U.S. servicemembers in the region, who are exposed to the highest risk of harm.

Name: Kustoff, David
text:
Before building one of the most influential companies in modern history, Fred Smith served his country with honor as a U.S. Marine Corps officer in Vietnam. After returning home, he continued his service by profound investment in our state and the great city of Memphis. 

It is hard to fully capture the impact he had on our city. His work and philanthropy touched every corner of Memphis. He invested in our children, our schools, our sports, and our future. Fred Smith gave hope to the people of Memphis because he believed so deeply in our potential.

I had the privilege of working with Fred Smith on many issues over the years. Ultimately, every effort was to further the best interests of our community. He never stopped showing up for Memphis. 

Fred Smith was a friend to all. He was a builder and a leader. I have no doubt that his legacy will live on forever. 

Roberta and I mourn his passing. Our thoughts and prayers are with Diane and the Smith family.

After giving every chance to negotiate a solution, President Trump has ended years of appeasement that has emboldened the¬†Iranian regime and its evil mullahs, the leading state sponsor of terror. It was an important and absolutely necessary step to neutralize a direct nuclear threat to regional and world peace and stability. This targeted action, only at nuclear sites,¬†dramatically reduces risk to America, our troops, and our steadfast ally, Israel. The United States will always stand resolutely against terrorism and aggression. The Iranian regime has been¬†disingenuous and unreliable - we've had no choice but to act.¬†In face of threats, you will be met with strength ‚Äì because that is how peace is kept. There is no greater force for freedom and stability than the U.S. God bless our troops and a mission that returns them, and keeps them, home.

Name: Titus, Dina
text:
.@POTUS has launched another war: one that Congress has not authorized, Nevadans don‚Äôt support, and Trump himself said he would never pursue.

Name: Rivas, Luz M.
text:
Tonight, I'm thinking of the safety of our troops, our nation, and the world. Donald Trump‚Äôs erratic action is unauthorized and unconstitutional. 

It is my hope that this does not increase escalations and engage our country into a prolonged military conflict and war in the Middle East.

Congress needs answers in a classified briefing as to why this action was taken, the potential threats as a result of this action, and the adverse effects to follow. 

Let us be clear ‚Äì this is once again Trump putting his ego before our troops, Americans, and peace.

Name: Fitzgerald, Scott
text:
Today‚Äôs U.S. strikes on Iran‚Äôs nuclear sites represent strong, decisive action fully within President Trump‚Äôs constitutional authority as Commander in Chief. By targeting Fordow, Natanz, and Esfahan, the Administration has significantly degraded Tehran‚Äôs nuclear capabilities and disrupted a looming threat to global security.

This action was not taken lightly, but with resolve, responsibility, and in pursuit of a more stable and peaceful future. By reducing Iran‚Äôs capacity to develop a nuclear weapon, these strikes send a clear and unmistakable message: America will act swiftly and with precision to defend our national interests and those of our allies.

Now is the time for Iran to reassess its path and choose negotiation over provocation. While diplomacy should always remain our preferred path, I fully support President Trump‚Äôs use of legitimate, constitutional authority to protect the United States and prevent a far greater conflict down the road.

Name: McConnell, Mitch
text:
Iran‚Äôs war on America and Israel spans decades. The history of the Islamic Republic is written in American, Israeli, and Arab blood, as well as that of the Iranian people. The regime‚Äôs survival has depended on repression at home and web of proxy terrorism and aggression abroad, underpinned by an obsessive pursuit of nuclear weapons.

Israel‚Äôs bold response to the war thrust upon it by Iran‚Äôs proxies has created a unique opportunity to cripple Iran‚Äôs nuclear ambitions and strike a lasting blow to its hegemonic aggression. Seizing this opportunity is not an escalation toward war ‚Äî it is a prudent response to the warmongers in Tehran. Iran would be foolish to misunderstand American resolve.

I commend the President for authorizing decisive action and all U.S. servicemembers responsible for carrying it out. The United States‚Äô interest in denying Iran a nuclear weapon, in standing with our ally, Israel, and in reestablishing credible deterrent power is undeniable and urgent.

Name: Jacobs, Sara
text: President Trump just threatened additional (and still congressionally unauthorized!) U.S. military strikes on Iran if they don‚Äôt come to the table. Additional strikes ‚Äî and even threats of them ‚Äî endanger the lives of our service members and millions of civilians in the region. It‚Äôs clear there is no real strategy here.

Name: Stanton, Greg
text:
I‚Äôm grateful to our service members tonight who carried out their missions with courage and competence, and I thank God for their safe return.

I have many serious questions about the President‚Äôs decision tonight. He failed to present clear and compelling evidence or come to Congress for authorization.

President Trump promised, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to start a war,‚Äù and ‚ÄúGreat nations do not fight endless wars.‚Äù That promise is now broken. This escalation risks dragging us into yet another endless war we cannot afford, and one that risks American lives.

President Trump must immediately reassure the American people of how he will protect the safety of our troops and allies in the region, and move us toward de-escalation and ultimately peace.

Name: Houlahan, Chrissy
text: We have bombed a nation we are not at war with and have done so without Congress knowing about it, voting on it or approving it. President Trump‚Äôs actions are not only unconstitutional‚Äîthey are dangerous. As Ranking Member of the Military Personnel Subcommittee I am especially concerned for our service members, their families and other Americans who are in the region and request an immediate briefing on the full details. The Trump administration must brief Congress immediately and fully on this action and the Americans currently in the region who are at risk, and must also come before Congress as required before taking any further action.

Name: Pelosi, Nancy

I join my colleagues in demanding answers from the Administration on this operation which endangers American lives and risks further escalation and dangerous destabilization of the region.

Name: Thanedar, Shri
text:
This evening, the United States military successfully conducted strikes on three of Iran's nuclear facilities. Our military is the best in the world and carried out the mission with skill and precision. Iran must never obtain a nuclear weapon.

However, these are wartime actions and the power to wage war lies solely with Congress. President Trump failed to get congressional approval for these strikes. He must not take further action without specific authorization by the United States Congress.

The best outcome now is a swift, diplomatic resolution that results in a complete dismantling of the Iranian nuclear program once and for all.

Name: Neal, Richard E.
text:
Tonight, President Trump offered the American people no strategy and no justification for his attack on Iran ‚Äî only the prospect of another war that the American people do not want. That‚Äôs why Congress, as the voice of the people, is entrusted with the constitutional authority to decide matters of war.

I pray for the safety of our troops and the American lives that have been put in harm‚Äôs way in the region.

Congress must return to Washington to assert its authority and prevent any further unchecked escalation. The only path to peace in the region is one where we exhaust every avenue of diplomacy.

Name: Dexter, Maxine
text: The power to declare war lies solely with the United States Congress. President Trump‚Äôs decision to launch direct military action against Iran without Congressional approval is unconstitutional and deeply reckless. As a mother, I am fervently committed to protecting our children from another endless war. The American people and our brave service members deserve answers, and I will demand the Trump administration provide them.

Name: Coons, Christopher A.
text:
I‚Äôm keeping American troops in the Middle East in my prayers tonight. 

The power to declare war rests with Congress.¬†As I said earlier this week, President Trump must consult with Congress, brief us on his plans to avoid escalation, and seek legal authorization for his actions. 

If successful, permanently knocking out Iran‚Äôs dangerous nuclear enrichment program would be a significant accomplishment. But the potential costs of these airstrikes, including potential retaliation on American servicemembers around the world, and the risk of another prolonged war in the Middle East, are enormous. It‚Äôs unclear whether this administration has thought through these consequences and Congress has an essential role.

Name: Schakowsky, Janice D.

President Trump‚Äôs actions are unconstitutional. Only Congress has the power to declare war. Congress must immediately vote on the bipartisan War Powers Resolution. 

Everyone must disengage and come to the table.

Name: Murphy, Christopher
text:
Donald Trump, a weak and dangerously reckless president, has put the United States on a path to a war in the Middle East that the country does not want, the law does not allow, and our security does not demand. 

Our president knows nothing about history. And history tells us that the United States' hubris about the efficacy of military action in the Middle East is almost universally wrong. Trump  has been goaded into these strikes by the perpetual cheerleaders of war in the Middle East - the people who know how to start conflicts there but never know how to end them, and the people who profit - politically and financially - from endless war.

I've been briefed on the intelligence - there is no evidence Iran posed an imminent threat to the United States. That makes this attack illegal. Only Congress can declare preemptive war, and we should vote as soon as possible on legislation to explicitly deny President Trump the authorization to drag us into a conflict in Middle East that could get countless Americans killed and waste trillions of dollars.

All my thoughts tonight are for the safety of our personnel in the region.

Name: Panetta, Jimmy
text:
The President promised to end forever wars, but tonight‚Äôs actions could escalate tensions, destabilize the region, and drag the United States into an avoidable conflict. Although Iran‚Äôs nuclear enrichment capabilities may now be degraded, its knowledge, geology, and desire to obtain nuclear weapons remain.

My full statement on this Administration's strikes on Iran:

Name: Kim, Andy
text: WILL US FORCES BE PROTECTED? There are around 40k American servicemembers in the Middle East right now. What is the administration doing to ensure the protection of our personnel and facilities? What will be the scope of Iranian retaliation? 2/15

Name: Kim, Andy

Name: Aderholt, Robert B.
text: There are crisis points in history when leaders must decide whether to take the Winston Churchill path or the Neville Chamberlain path. Tonight, President Trump has chosen the Churchill path, recognizing‚Äîjust as Churchill did‚Äîthat you cannot negotiate with a regime that continually calls for the destruction of Israel and America, just as it was impossible to negotiate with Nazi Germany.

Name: Slotkin, Elissa
text:
I expect a full, classified brief on the strikes in Iran, and the strategy and force protection plans, as soon as possible.  

In the meantime, tonight I‚Äôm focused on the safety of the over 40,000 U.S. forces in the Middle East, and their loved ones back home, concerned about retaliation and what comes next.
 
While it‚Äôs too early to know the results, a successful strike by our capable military wasn‚Äôt the primary question. 
 
The real question is: what happens the day after? A strike can have major repercussions for safety and stability across the region. As someone who served in Iraq and saw up close the loss of blood and treasure over 20 years, I don‚Äôt want to be embroiled in another drawn out conflict, and neither do the American people.

This is exactly why our founders built a role for Congress on issues of war and peace ‚Äî to ensure questions of real consequence are answered before American men and women are engaged in war.

Name: Bilirakis, Gus M.
text: For years, the Iranian regime has openly called for the destruction of Israel and the United States, sponsored terrorism across the globe, attacked American interests, and fueled the spread of radical Islamist ideology. In the face of such persistent aggression, the United States had no choice but to take decisive action to prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear-armed state.  I commend President Trump for authorizing targeted strikes on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities‚Äîan essential step toward preserving both regional and global security. And I am grateful to the brave men and women who executed this mission with skill and precision.  We stand firmly with our ally Israel in confronting this shared threat. Peace and stability in the Middle East depend on strong, decisive action‚Äîand that action has now been taken.  Hopefully, Tehran will recognize that its best path forward lies not in escalation or confrontation, but in choosing diplomacy, de-escalation, and a commitment to lasting peace.

Name: Trahan, Lori
text:
My statement on President Trump's unauthorized U.S. military strikes in Iran:

I am deeply grateful that the American servicemembers who carried out this mission returned safely. Their professionalism, precision, and bravery are unmatched, and we owe them and their families a debt of gratitude for their unwavering commitment to our country.

Absolutely no one wants to see the Iranian regime acquire nuclear weapons. That shared goal has guided years of bipartisan diplomatic and strategic engagement to prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear-armed state. President Trump‚Äôs decision to launch direct military strikes without congressional approval threatens to undermine those efforts and drag the United States into another costly, endless war in the Middle East.

Acting without the consent of Congress, without a clear strategy, and without the backing of our allies puts American lives at risk and risks further destabilizing an already volatile region. It also flies in the face of the president‚Äôs campaign promise to de-escalate tensions in the Middle East, end the war in Gaza, and bring home the hostages still held by Hamas.

For decades, Iran has been the largest state sponsor of terrorism, causing chaos in the Middle East, and putting Americans and our allies in danger. For them to obtain a nuclear weapon would make peace in the Middle East unachievable and make our country and our world an unsafe place.

Last night, America‚Äôs armed forces carried out an attack on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities. I am relieved none of our brave American service men and women were hurt.

Like most Michiganders, I believe the last thing our country needs is to be involved in another foreign war. Any further action must receive approval from Congress. I intend to use my power as a member of Congress to ensure that this president and this administration do not continue to abuse the system of checks and balances we have in this country. I am also demanding that the Trump administration give Congress a briefing and give us intelligence rationale for this attack and ongoing threats in the region.

We also must focus on protecting American troops and civilians in the region, and work to evacuate Americans where needed. If any Michiganders are currently in Israel or the Middle East and need help getting home, please contact our district office (734-853-3040), who has staff standing by ready to assist.

These strikes also risk entangling the United States in another costly war in the Middle East ‚Äî something Donald Trump explicitly and repeatedly told the American people he would avoid.

I continue to demand a briefing from the Administration on this volatile situation. President Trump owes the nation ‚Äî especially the families of service members now in harm‚Äôs way ‚Äî honest answers about this decision.

At this moment of uncertainty, our top priority must be protecting American military and diplomatic personnel in the region. I join members of both parties in praying for their safety.

Name: Barr, Andy
text: THREAD üßµ Critics of President @realDonaldTrump‚Äôs bold and decisive action to defend the United States from a nuclear Iran are dead wrong.  Apparently, they want to write Article II completely out of the Constitution. The President acted fully within his constitutional authority.

Name: Barr, Andy
text: Congress has not only declined to exercise those powers, Congress has acted repeatedly to sanction Iran, provide military support to Israel, and approve defense appropriations specifically designed for this kind of military action.

Name: Barr, Andy
text: He possesses the power to carry out military action as Commander-in-Chief under Article II of the Constitution, checked only by Congress's power of the purse and arguably the War Powers Resolution.

Name: Barr, Andy

Name: Ryan, Patrick
text:
I love our country. I served in America‚Äôs longest wars, where I saw the best of humanity in my fellow veterans‚Äô heroism and selfless service (much like we witnessed last night); and saw the worst of humanity and horrors of war up close and personal.¬†

Twenty years ago, in their rush to appear strong and tough, politicians ‚Äì from both parties ‚Äì failed to ask the hard questions before starting wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Now, trillions of dollars and countless deaths later, we still haven‚Äôt gotten accountability.

America must not make those same mistakes again.¬†

I am under no illusions about the nature of the Iranian regime and its proxies ‚Äì they are evil. We must continue to stand strongly with our Israeli allies ‚Äì including active and robust support for the defense of the state of Israel and its people, as we have for decades.¬†¬†

But Trump‚Äôs actions last night, taken without any case being made to the American people or the Congress, coupled with his speech doubling down on his sole authority to further escalate the conflict, risks repeating history and starting another forever war in the Middle East.¬†

The Constitution explicitly grants the power to make war to Congress, on behalf of the American people ‚Äì not the President. I am supporting the War Powers Resolution because we must act immediately to reclaim that authority.

Name: Cantwell, Maria
text: The United States should work to do everything it can to avoid a larger war with Iran or a larger Middle East conflict. It requires working with our allies and the international community to move towards diplomatic solutions that ensure that Iran is no longer a state sponsor of terrorism and national security threat. Congress should work to pass the Enhanced Iranian Sanctions Act. Congress must also reassert its constitutional authorities to head off future reckless or shortsighted Presidential actions on issues of war and trade. The United States must rebuild the international coalition of allies and partners forged under the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and build on it by penalizing countries that break international sanctions and buy Iranian oil at discounted prices. The JCPOA provided the right framework, and we should work with the International Atomic Energy Agency to get back to that approach. Diplomacy and alliance building are the only long-term solutions that will bring about an enduring peace and prosperity in the Middle East.

Name: Norcross, Donald
text:
Since 1979, the Iranian government has called for the destruction of the United States and Israel, and it remains the world‚Äôs leading sponsor of terrorism, funding Hamas, Hezbollah, the Houthis, and others.¬†
¬†
A nuclear Iran is a serious threat to Americans and our democratic ally, Israel. Operation Midnight Hammer succeeded in setting back that effort, and I‚Äôm grateful to the U.S. service members involved in the operation.¬†
¬†
It's deeply troubling that only Republican lawmakers were briefed before the operation. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee, I will be briefed on the details of this operation and will request the intelligence that justified the operation. National security is not a red or blue issue, it‚Äôs an American issue.
¬†
The world is safer with the degradation of Iran's nuclear capabilities and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reported there are undeclared nuclear material and activities in Iran. For decades, Iran has been expanding its nuclear capabilities, its ballistic missile program, and funded terrorism that‚Äôs dangerous to American security.¬†
¬†
We must weigh the long-term implications of this action and the possibility that it could lead us into an avoidable war. Only Congress has the power to declare war and I encourage further diplomatic negotiations to de-escalate this conflict.

Name: Greene, Marjorie Taylor
text:
My thoughts on bombing Iran.

I don‚Äôt know anyone in America who has been the victim of a crime or killed by Iran, but I know many people who have been victims of crime committed by criminal illegal aliens or MURDERED by Cartel and Chinese fentanyl/drugs. 

Almost everyone in our country can relate to this fact. 

However America has not dropped bunker busters on the Cartel‚Äôs sophisticated drug tunnels, launched tomahawks on massive cartel poisonous drug operations, or gone to war against the cartels international terrorists networks.

Neocon warmongers beat their drums of war and act like Billy badasses going to war in countries most Americans have never seen and can‚Äôt find on a map, but never find the courage to go to war against the actual terrorists who actually do kill Americans, invade our land, and make BILLIONS doing it day after day, year after year.

I‚Äôm 51 years old. I‚Äôm GenX. 

I‚Äôve watched our country go to war in foreign lands for foreign causes on behalf of foreign interests for as long as I can remember. I was in 10th grade when Desert Storm started and my father before me was sent to Vietnam, another senseless foreign war. 

America is $37 TRILLION in debt and all of these foreign wars have cost Americans TRILLIONS AND TRILLIONS of dollars that never benefited any American.

American troops have been killed and forever torn apart physically and mentally for regime change, foreign wars, and for military industrial base profits. 

I‚Äôm sick of it. 

I can easily say I support nuclear armed Israel‚Äôs right to defend themselves and also say at the same time I don‚Äôt want to fight or fund nuclear armed Israel‚Äôs wars. 

Nor any other country for that matter. 

I‚Äôm sick of funding foreign aid and foreign countries and foreign everything. 

I want to fund American interests and issues.

I want GREAT trade deals so American businesses and people can afford goods and be successful.

I want low inflation and low interest rates.

I want American construction, housing, and manufacturing to BOOM.

I want Americans to be rich and have security in their future.

I want my children‚Äôs generation to HAVE A GREAT FUTURE!!!

My kids are 22, 25, and 27. 

It pisses me off beyond comprehension that my children‚Äôs generation can‚Äôt afford to buy a house, can‚Äôt afford insurance, and have little hope for their future!!! 

Americans are exhausted by all of this and rightfully so. 

I can also support President Trump and his great administration on many of the great things they are doing while disagreeing on bombing Iran and getting involved in a hot war that Israel started.

That‚Äôs not disloyalty. Critical thinking and having my own opinions is the most American thing ever.

Because contrary to what brainwashed Democrat boomers say, Trump is not a king, MAGA is not a cult, and President Trump has surrounded himself with people who once disagreed with him and even ran against him for President.

Also the same Democrats in Congress that are all of sudden clutching their pearls about Trump bombing Iran FULLY SUPPORTED AND VOTED TO FUND Dementia ridden Biden‚Äôs proxy war against Russia in Ukraine and stood by Biden‚Äôs disastrous withdrawal from Afghanistan.

Hypocrites is all they are and they are just desperately trying to find solid ground to oppose Trump on because so far they‚Äôve failed at grasping anything yet.

Now what has been done is done and Americans now fear Iranian terrorists attacks on our own soil and being dragged into another war by Netanyahu when we weren‚Äôt even thinking about any of this a week ago.

We don‚Äôt know what the future holds and I pray for the safety of all people and an end to the constant demand for America to go to war.

Enough is enough.

Name: Bell, Wesley
text:
I'm grateful that no American service members were harmed in this strike, and proud of the skill and bravery of the Missouri-based airmen and airwomen who carried out their mission. Our troops always deserve our respect, no matter who is president.

I never for a second doubted our military's ability to strike its targets. But taking out facilities is the easy part. It's what comes next that's hard-and we've seen how this story goes.

Launching airstrikes without consulting Congress, without a clear strategy, and without providing transparency to the American people is not an acceptable path forward. I am also extremely worried that the massive risk of escalation will further put our service members at risk.

If we desire peace in the region, we can never allow Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon. It would be incredibly naive to believe that if Iran obtained a nuclear weapon that they would not use it. But the Administration has an obligation to brief Congress and outline their objectives for the timing of this action. We cannot be dragged into another war in the Middle East by those who have learned nothing from the last two decades.

I've talked with many people across St. Louis-families, veterans, workers‚Äî and they deserve answers. And our troops, especially those from right here in Missouri, deserve better than being sent into harm's way without a clear mission or long-term plan.

Name: Schrier, Kim
text:
President Trump‚Äôs unilateral decision, made without proper consultation with Congress, will have widespread consequences that we cannot predict.

We know Iran is the number one state sponsor of terrorism around the world and must never possess a nuclear weapon. There is no guarantee that yesterday‚Äôs actions will permanently achieve that goal, and none of us want the U.S. pulled into another endless war in the Middle East that puts our country and brave servicemembers at extreme risk.

Any further action must happen in consultation with Congress. As a member of Congress, I intend to use my power to ensure the safety of our nation and ensure that the Administration does not continue to circumvent the systems of checks and balances fundamental to our democracy. The Trump Administration must provide Congress with a briefing and an opportunity to ask questions regarding the intelligence used to justify this action, and which could inform future actions in the region.

I will continue to monitor the unfolding situation and pray for the safety of our servicemembers and all civilians in the region at this dangerous time.

We must do everything possible to de-escalate and foster lasting diplomacy, peace, and stability in the Middle East.

Name: Steube, W. Gregory
text:
As a lawyer, a veteran who wore the uniform, and a JAG who served in Operation Iraqi Freedom, I can say unequivocally: you‚Äôre wrong, @RepThomasMassie.

President Trump has full constitutional authority to take military action against Iran‚Äôs nuclear program without a formal declaration of war. Article II, Section 2 empowers the Commander in Chief to use the Armed Forces to defend national interests and respond to imminent threats. The War Powers Resolution of 1973 allows a 60-day window, plus a 30-day withdrawal period, as long as Congress is notified within 48 hours. Claims that his actions were unconstitutional are simply false.

We all know Iran and its proxies were actively seeking nuclear weapons and targeting American troops and allies. President Trump stepped up and stopped them. I‚Äôm glad we have a Commander in Chief who eliminates terrorists instead of pandering to them, like you do.

Name: Murkowski, Lisa
text:
Over the last 24 hours, the administration laid out its rationale for striking Iran‚Äôs nuclear infrastructure. President Trump described these as precision strikes on three key nuclear facilities, stressing that Iran must now choose peace. I am encouraged by the administration's assurance that these strikes were deliberately limited in scope, and I hope the Pentagon can soon confirm that Iran‚Äôs nuclear capabilities have been neutralized.

While it is unclear how Iran will respond, I urge the regime to resist escalation and to come to the table to negotiate a peaceful resolution. The world was never going to allow them to possess nuclear weapons, and no one should want or allow this to spiral into a protracted fight that results in lives lost and further destabilization of the region.

My colleagues and I will receive a classified briefing later this week to assess the scope of the operation, the administration‚Äôs strategy, and the legal justification.¬†I remain hopeful these limited strikes greatly advanced our national security objectives, but if it is clear this is becoming a wider conflict, we must remember that Congress alone holds the constitutional power to authorize war.

As we go forward, I am praying for the safety of our troops, American personnel abroad, and for peace in the region.

Israel is a longstanding, strategic, and democratic ally in the Middle East. Any threat to its existence is a threat to America‚Äôs national security interests.

Iran is run by a terrorist regime who has unequivocally stated their intention to develop nuclear weapons in order to destroy Israel.  

The Iranian regime has also repeatedly stated their next target - should they succeed in defeating Israel - will be America.  

Rule number one in self defense:  when someone threatens the lives of you and your family, believe them; and, then do everything in your power to prevent it. 

The previous Administration didn‚Äôt understand that basic principle and their policy of appeasement was received by allies and enemies alike as weakness, which only emboldened Iran to accelerate their nuclear power ambitions.

President Trump doesn‚Äôt want war, but peace requires a willing partner.  The Iranian regime has shown no change in policy or posture including ending their nuclear weapons program, killing American troops, funding terrorists in the region, and supporting Hamas‚Äô October 2023 terrorist attack on Israel.

Iran mistook Trump‚Äôs reluctance for war as an unwillingness to use force.  Now they know.  If Iran doesn‚Äôt come to the table soon or decides to strike American targets, President Trump‚Äôs patience for diplomacy will quickly expire.

‚ñ™Ô∏èH.R. 1266, the Combating Illicit Xylazine Act, legislation to target the drug and smuggling operations associated with it, which has become a potent counterpart to fentanyl, as its use extends beyond a tranquilizer to a dangerous opioid capable of resulting in poisonings and overdoses.

‚ñ™Ô∏èH.R. 1383, the Secure Rural Schools Reauthorization Act of 2025, a bill to ensure continued security payments for schools operating on federal land and prevent against any funding shortfalls that could put students at risk of safety threats.

‚ñ™Ô∏èH.R. 1065, the Protect Our Letter Carriers Act of 2025, legislation to require the Department of Justice to appoint an assistant U.S. attorney in each judicial district to coordinate and supervise the investigation and prosecution of various crimes related to postal services.

This weekend, I joined @BuffaloNAACP for the 57th Annual Medgar Evers Awards Gala, a powerful celebration of justice, equity, and community. I am grateful to Rev. Mark Blue for his leadership and to all the honorees who are carrying this fight forward.

It was my privilege to introduce @SenatorWarnock, whose leadership helped change the course of American history. In a historic runoff, the people of Georgia elected him as the state's first Black U.S. Senator.

His victory allowed for the passage of transformative legislation providing trillions of dollars in investments in communities nationwide.

Reverend Warnock is more than a trailblazing Senator, he is the Senior Pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, the spiritual home of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.¬†¬†

He has spent his entire life at the intersection of faith and public service. It is an honor to call him a colleague.

Name: Pappas, Chris
text:
I am grateful that all U.S. military personnel involved in this weekend‚Äôs strike have returned safely after completing their mission, and I thank them for their courage and professionalism. Iran is a terrorist state that must never be allowed to possess a nuclear weapon, a development that would threaten American national security and the very existence of our ally, Israel. In the wake of the strike on Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities, I call on the Trump Administration to re-engage in diplomacy and prioritize the safety of all American service members and civilians in the region.

Granite Staters do not want our country to be drawn into another endless war in the Middle East. It is the role of Congress to consider and approve the deployment of U.S. military power to wage war, not a unilateral decision to be made by the President. That is why the administration must come to Congress immediately to answer questions about this attack and present a plan to protect our service members and national security interests.

Administrations of both parties have, for too long, operated beyond the powers granted to them by the Constitution and the law. I have consistently argued during my time in office that Congress must reassert its authority to determine the appropriate use of military force and prevent the United States from getting bogged down in conflicts. That is why I will support H. Con. Res. 38 and will continue to review additional measures to restore this check and affirm the role of Congress to debate and approve future military action.

Name: Gallego, Ruben
text:
The budget plan that Congressional Republicans are trying to pass is packed with cuts to programs that millions of Americans rely on, but one of the cruelest is cuts to food assistance like SNAP and Free and Reduced Lunch. These programs are lifelines for thousands of families in Arizona.

This is personal for me. When I was a kid, my three sisters and I relied on free lunch at school. That tray meant my mom could breathe a little easier and I could just be a kid.

That‚Äôs what Republicans in Congress are threatening to rip away from tens of thousands of kids in Arizona. These are kids who don‚Äôt have a lobbyist and who didn‚Äôt ask to be caught in a political fight but got caught in one anyway.

I'm not being dramatic; this isn‚Äôt a hypothetical. Under the budget that House Republicans narrowly passed last month, 63,000 Arizona families are at risk of losing some or all of their SNAP benefits. Kicking kids off SNAP will also make it harder for schools to qualify for federal school meal funding, impacting 121,693 Arizona students.

These cuts aren‚Äôt just bad policy. They‚Äôre a moral failure.

The United States is the richest country in the history of the world. We shouldn‚Äôt accept moms opening the fridge and having to decide who skips dinner like it‚Äôs normal. We shouldn‚Äôt accept second graders sitting through math class on an empty stomach. We have enough to make sure kids in Arizona get lunch at school and that families can put food on the table. We just have to decide that‚Äôs what matters.

I‚Äôm going to fight like hell to stop these cuts. Because no kid should go hungry in America while billionaires are getting more tax breaks.

Name: Golden, Jared F.
text:
Iran is governed by a regime that is hostile to the United States and allied with others that seek the destruction of America. They sponsor terrorist organizations that have killed American troops and citizens and are a source of chaos and bloodshed in the region. 

The IAEA determined the regime had been dangerously close to developing nuclear weapons. Based on what I know so far, I believe the president was right to launch limited strikes to deter that outcome.

It is important now that the country learns what information helped inform the president‚Äôs decision and the timing of these strikes, and that we learn more about whether we were successful in destroying Iran‚Äôs nuclear program. I look forward to Congress receiving a full briefing.

But what matters most now is what happens next: Just today, Iran launched missiles at American bases in Iraq and Qatar. The top priority for the president and his administration, as well as for Congress, must be to use every tool at our disposal to defend Americans and deter further escalation by Tehran.

Today‚Äôs decision by the @USDA to rescind the deeply flawed and outdated Roadless Rule is yet another a major victory for Alaska. 

Alaska‚Äôs forests are one of our state‚Äôs greatest natural assets and the ‚ÄúRoadless Rule‚Äù has long stifled responsible forest management, blocked access to critical resources, and halted economic opportunity 
particularly in Alaska, where 92% of the Tongass National Forest was off-limits.

The Roadless Rule was never about responsible conservation; it was about bureaucratic overreach that undermined the ability of local forest managers and communities to effectively manage their lands. 

I commend Secretary Rollins and President Trump for their leadership in advancing this commonsense reform. By removing these blanket prohibitions, the Administration is restoring the authority of local leaders to manage our forests correctly.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
Hopefully we are now on the path to peace‚Ä¶

6 thoughts on Saturday‚Äôs strike, the regime‚Äôs response, and where we go from here. üßµüëáüèº

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
We know that the Iranian regime is pursuing a nuclear weapon. The question is, how close are they to having the bomb?

The strikes set them back. Significantly, we hope.

No one is talking about sending in troops or regime change (in any real way). I oppose both.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
2. This is not Iraq.

In 2003, the Administration lied about weapons of mass destruction, sent in troops, and forced a regime change.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
1. The Iranian regime cannot acquire a nuclear weapon.

This weekend‚Äôs targeted, defensive strikes on nuclear enrichment facilities may be the best way to prevent what could be a catastrophic war - and to get the regime to negotiate terms for a sustainable peace in the Middle East.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
3. It was a serious military action, and Trump should have briefed key Republican and Democratic members of Congress before taking the action. 

Reports suggest he only called Republicans. This must be bipartisan.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
4. Declaring war does require Congressional action. This would be troops on the ground.

The goal of this strike was to prevent war.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
5. The Iranian regime‚Äôs attacks on our military bases in the region were intercepted by the Qataris. This is a good sign.

My hope is that this is an attempt to de-escalate. Reports suggest that the Iranian regime coordinated with the Qataris.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
We need leadership that brings countries together, particularly in Europe and the Middle East, and that unites Republicans and Democrats in working toward peace.

There is a path to peace and security in the Middle East, and I hope this is it.

Name: Landsman, Greg
text:
6. Next steps will determine everything.

I will advocate that this Administration build the broadest bipartisan coalition possible to reach the right agreement with the Iranian regime: remove all enriched uranium, accept around-the-clock inspections, pursue only civilian nuclear programs, and dismantle their terror armies.

Name: LaMalfa, Doug
text:
The Forest Service is finally beginning the process to repeal the 2001 Roadless Rule‚Äîa policy that‚Äôs done more harm than good in the West. As Secretary Rollins made clear, the rule has blocked responsible forest management for over two decades, preventing thinning, logging, and the ability to build roads that are critical for wildfire response and public safety.

This was a Clinton-era regulation pushed through in the final days of that administration, backed by environmental activists with no stake in what actually happens on the ground. The result was more overgrown forests, more catastrophic wildfires, and fewer jobs in rural counties that rely on active forest work to sustain their economies.

Repealing the Roadless Rule won‚Äôt fix everything overnight, but it‚Äôs a major step toward restoring common-sense forest management and giving local experts the ability to do their jobs.

While our laws already prohibit direct aid to terrorist groups, this bill requires the State Department to pressure others to cut ties with regimes like the Taliban and report back to Congress to increase transparency. This is a commonsense step to strengthen oversight, bolster national security, and stop global aid from propping up our enemies.

Name: Pressley, Ayanna
text:
Trump and Republicans‚Äô Big, Ugly Bill wouldn‚Äôt just slash Medicaid and food assistance for millions of people‚Äîit is also a brazen attack on reproductive healthcare and a backdoor abortion ban, even for safe-haven states like Massachusetts.

This bill would defund Planned Parenthood health centers, bar private health insurers on the ACA marketplace from offering abortion coverage, and slash Medicaid health care coverage ‚Äî leaving over 300,000 Massachusetts residents unable to access basic health care services.

The cruelty is truly the point.

As we begin to mark three years since the Supreme Court ripped away the basic right to abortion care in America, I stood with @WhipKClark, @SenWarren, and @RepLoriTrahan in proud solidarity with Planned Parenthood in the fight to stop Republicans‚Äô latest attack on reproductive freedom.

Planned Parenthood clinics are quite literally saving lives ‚Äì often the only option for miles for life saving cancer screenings, affordable birth control, & compassionate prenatal care.

As a college student, I went to Planned Parenthood and was diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Later, as a survivor of campus sexual assault, I returned to Planned Parenthood for counseling and STI testing. So this is deeply personal to me.

We must keep fighting for families across this country to access the basic medical care they need to survive, to be safe in birth, to be treated with human dignity.

And that starts by defeating Republicans‚Äô Big Ugly Bill that puts necessary health care further out of reach for millions of people.

Name: Banks, Jim
text:
During his first term in office, President Trump‚Äôs foreign policy was the textbook case of peace through strength. 

He built closer ties with our allies in Asia. 

He also negotiated the historic Abraham Accords, while fostering stronger relations with our neighbors in America‚Äôs backyard.

Name: Banks, Jim
text:
At the same time, President Trump put America‚Äôs enemies on notice, reversing the Obama years of appeasement.

He eliminated ISIS, killing its leader, Al-Baghdadi.

Trump also took out Qasem Soleimani, the senior Iranian general who had American blood on his hands.

Name: Banks, Jim
text: Just as he did with his decisions to take out Al-Baghdadi and Soleimani, Trump put America‚Äôs enemies on notice Saturday night with his strikes against Iran‚Äôs nuclear facilities.

Name: Banks, Jim
text:
Other countries in the Middle East like Saudi Arabia and the UAE have already condemned Iran‚Äôs retaliatory strike on our military base in Qatar.¬†

Iran is now finding itself isolated & without any allies in the region, because President Trump was unafraid to enforce his red line against Tehran. They know that Trump wasn‚Äôt bluffing.

Name: Banks, Jim
text:
The President and his foreign policy team gave Iran opportunity after opportunity to come to the negotiating table and make a deal.

At the same time, President Trump was consistent that Tehran could not be allowed to obtain a nuclear weapon as part of any deal. 

But when Tehran refused, the President was left with no choice but to send a message that America would no longer sit back and allow our enemies to threaten our national security or that of our allies.

Name: Banks, Jim

The last 4 years have shown us that weak leadership at home enables hostile regimes to test America‚Äôs limits.

text: Although the appointees to ACIP have scientific credentials, many do not have significant experience studying microbiology, epidemiology or immunology. In particular, some lack experience studying new technologies such as mRNA vaccines, and may even have a preconceived bias against them. Robust and transparent scientific discussion is important, so long as it is rooted in evidence and understanding. Wednesday's meeting should not proceed with a relatively small panel, and no CDC Director in place to approve the panel's recommendations. The meeting should be delayed until the panel is fully staffed with more robust and balanced representation‚Äîas required by law‚Äîincluding those with more direct relevant expertise. Otherwise, ACIP‚Äôs recommendations could be viewed with skepticism, which will work against the success of this Administration's efforts.

Name: Nadler, Jerrold
text:
I welcome the news of a ceasefire between Israel and Iran. The violence has cost too many innocent lives and inflicted too much destruction on innocent civilians.
 
As I return to Washington this evening, I look forward to learning more about the impact the United States‚Äô attack has had on Iran‚Äôs nuclear capabilities. While I continue to affirm the importance of American assistance and action to defend Israel and am clear-eyed about Iran‚Äôs state sponsor of terrorist proxies throughout the region, I also remain resolute that, regardless of the outcome, the Trump Administration‚Äôs military action against Iran was unconstitutional, as only Congress has the power to authorize the use of military force. 
 
Today‚Äôs ceasefire announcement is but one step. I pray that this ceasefire puts us on a path in the Middle East to realize the vision articulated in the book of Isaiah: ‚Äúnation shall not lift up sword against nation; neither shall they learn war anymore.‚Äù
